Hi:
 At first glance it does look rather nice, however the mei looks
tentative, soft and not quite right to me. The first thing one would
what to do is to consult the book of Akiyama collected Nobuiye (title
escapes me without reference material here) which illustrates the vast
bulk of know Nobuiye out there. A few years ago a well known California
dealer was lucky enough to find one at a show, bought it and it
eventually went Juyo. Sure enough is found among the Akiyama oshigata.
You can be quite sure that if such a tsuba left Japan and were correct
the price would have at least another zero on the end, and probably an
initial digit change as well.
 Arnold


>>> matthewhoyle@... 01/30/05 5:32 PM >>>

Gimei Nobuiye?

http://www.nihonto.com/11.28.04.html

Mr. Weissberg evidently thinks it is gimei, my question is how can you
tell?
It looks awfully similar to the ones in the books!

And if it is indeed gimei, how old is it do we think?

Matt
